messageBody:
sidban2 wrote:

> QuikSkript can be more difficult to read, especially when other people
> write it and have their unique connections to the letters.

Sid et al:

I have not read a lot of handwritten QS, but I have not found it
difficult to read in general. The biggest problem I see is not that the
script is difficult to read, but that individuals decide to start making
the letters differently than the QS manual sets out. For instance, in
your e-mail you comment that "other people have their unique connections
to the letters." This ignores the fact that the manual does not
authorize "unique connections" in forming the letters. When one letter
that ends where another starts, one does not have to make a pen-lift.
When they do not end at the same point, a pen-lift should always be made
because the shape of the QS letters are simpler than T.O. and additional
connecting lines added willy-nilly at the writer's whim will inevitably
cause legibility to suffer. One should not make connecting lines
between letters that do not join naturally. To do so is to revert back
to the practices of writing in Roman.

> Shavian Script is best printed as it is quite clear.

The meaning of the preceding sentence is unclear to me. Shavian is a
script with no connections between letters so what does "best printed"
mean? It only has what we term a "printed" form, i.e. no cursive form
of Shavian exists.

> > From: stbett
> > Sent: 8/31/2002 8:01:08 AM
> > To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone
> >
> > Hi Grant, welcome to the group.
> >
> > Issue #1: Shouldn't the base dialect be more neutral?
> >
> > Just because there is a base dialect does not mean that you have to
> > speak that way. It does mean that you have to be familiar with the
> > dialect if that is the basis of standardized spelling.
> >
> > snip...
> > It will be much easier for all to phonemically spell as an NBC
> > commentator speaks than as Queen Elizabeth spoke. I don't think the
> > issue is proper pronunciation. It is more a case of a pronunciation
> > that will be widely understood.

Everyone seems convinced that the use of QS or Shavian will require a
standardized spelling, which I feel is a hangover from the current
situation with T.O. I remain unconvinced. In my opinion, as soon as
you standardize the spelling, and people pronounce the words in the way
they are accustomed to, the alphabet stops being a relatively accurate
representation of speech and over time the divergence between spoken
English and written English will inevitably increase, and given enough
time, we will be back in the same boat we are in now. If we would keep
the spoken and written forms closely together, then some group would
have to be given authority to change the "official" spelling of words,
and the English-speaking world has no such group.

If I, as an American, can understand Australian English or British
English when spoken, I surely should be able to understand it when
written in QS. In fact, I corresponded with an New Zealand native in QS
in 1974 and had absolutely no problem understanding what he had written,
and we had no "standardized spelling."

Really obscure English dialects will probably not appear in print that
often in any event, and, if they did, and people could not comprehend
them, presumably the authors of such works would learn about that in
short order and make the necessary changes to alter their orthography to
the closest main-stream dialect.


Paige Gabhart
